best.why: It is the only version that successfully bridges the high-theory tone of the manifesto with the low-culture reality of 'slop' (referencing 'shrimp Christs' and 'six-fingered saints'). It articulates the core philosophical shift—from making to choosing—most clearly with the expansion on Duchamp at the end. It feels substantial enough to stand alongside the previous sections.

worst.why: It is too brief and breezy. The previous sections have a weight and a slightly sermon-like cadence; Version D feels like a summary of a paragraph rather than the paragraph itself. It lacks the 'bite' required to follow the aggression of Section IV.

must_survive_line: We are Duchamp's children in an age where everything is already a readymade — where the gesture is not choosing one urinal among many, but choosing one image among an infinity.
